sent_raw: 0,"The boy and the goddess tell me about a complicated man. muse, tell me how he wandered and was lost when he had wrecked the holy town of troy, and where he went, and who he met, the pain he suffered in the storms at sea, and how he worked to save his life and bring his men back home."
1,"he failed to keep them safe; poor fools, they ate the sun god s cattle, and the god kept them from home."
2,"now goddess, child of zeus, tell the old story for our modern times."
3,Find the beginning.
4,all the other greeks who had survived the brutal sack of troy sailed safely home to their own wives except this man alone.
5,"calypso, a great goddess, had trapped him in her cave; she wanted him to be her husband."
6,"when the year rolled round in which the gods decreed he should go home to ithaca, his troubles still went on."
7,the man was friendless.
8,"all the gods took pity, except poseidon s anger never ended"
9,Until odysseus was back at home.

11,"there sat the god, delighting in his banquet."
12,"the other gods were gathered on olympus, in father zeus palace."
13,"he was thinking of fine, well-born aegisthus, who was killed by agamemnon s famous son orestes."
14,"He told the deathless gods, this is absurd, that mortals blame the gods! they say we cause their suffering, but they themselves increase it by folly."
15,"so aegisthus overstepped: he took the legal wife of agamemnon, then killed the husband when he came back home, although he knew that it would doom them all."
16,"we gods had warned aegisthus; we sent down perceptive hermes, who flashed into sight and told him not to murder agamemnon"

18,aegisthus would not hear that good advice.

21,bring death to all who act like him! but i am agonizing about odysseus and his bad luck.

23,"Out on an island where a goddess lives, daughter of fearful atlas, who holds up the pillars of the sea, and knows its depths those pillars keep the heaven and earth apart."

24,"his daughter holds that poor unhappy man, and tries beguiling him with gentle words to cease all thoughts of ithaca; but he longs to see even just the smoke that rises from his own homeland, and he wants to die."
25,"you do not even care, olympian!"
26,Remember how he sacrificed to you on the broad plain of troy beside his ships?
